Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Metal Nanocomposites designed for Low Power Sintering for use in Additive Manufacturing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable a broad range of industries to quickly and relatively inexpensively create custom metal components. What before would have been impossible to do with traditional CNC machining, or cost-prohibitive to do with traditional direct metal laser sintering additive manufacturing, can now be accomplished with low cost equipment. This will allow businesses ranging from medical, to aerospace, to automotive to rapidly iterate on their designs and increase the pace of new developments. The impact on our society is difficult to predict, just as the impact of the Internet was also grossly underestimated with the way that it has now become part of our everyday lives. The innovation itself is to greatly lower the cost of creating custom metal parts, thus enabling a wide variety of other industries to flourish.


This project intends to create a new type of metal composite that works with low cost additive manufacturing equipment by finding new ways to direct energy into fusing the metal particles together. The innovation is in the choice of materials that enables the ease of processing. The anticipated technical results are the creation of proof of concept sample parts and a determination of their mechanical strength as compared to other more traditional methods of manufacturing. Often individuals with an idea for a new product or business are held back by the high cost of prototyping that limits it to only the largest, most established companies. The research addresses the current extremely high cost of using additive manufacturing to create custom metal parts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
MadeSolid’s NSF SBIR Phase I grant concerns a new additive manufacturing technology involving low energy and high resolution 3D printing of metals. Our technology, for convenience, has been dubbed ‘nanoink’, and the NSF grant MadeSolid received has been instrumental in helping our researchers gather data and perform previously prohibitively expensive characterization in regards to our nanoink and nanoink printing technology and contributed to successful funding of R&D by outside sources, as well as generate significant industry interest fueling commercialization. Beyond metal ‘nanoink’  MadeSolid also discovered and showed our technology was more broadly applicable to a wide variety of materials, as the basic physics suggested, to that of ceramics, both oxide and non-oxide, glass, and polymers as well.

Our technology is a combination of efficient conversion of light into heat with the material ‘ink’ being in an optional liquid form. Our goal is to lower the cost and increase the resolution of 3D Printing in metals. During the course of our work, we also discovered new solvents with commercial uses outside of 3D Printing, new compounds that convert light into heat, and new methods for manufacturing and 3D Printing based on derivatives of our basic process. Scientific characterization of our nanoinks and printed material included such techniques as SEM, scanning electron microscopy, XRD, x-ray diffraction, spectrophotometric and thermographic techniques. Prior to MadeSolid approaching the NSF it was difficult to pitch our nanoink to investors in Silicon Valley, as it was a technically challenging endeavor with a longer path to commercialization than we could support as a small startup company.

Our grant work has spawned multiple products added to our roadmap based on the technology, intellectual property in the form of trade secrets and patents, as well as commercial interest from Fortune 500 companies to further develop our technology.

Additionally, MadeSolid’s R&D team was able to explore fundamental questions about materials at the nanoscale, some examples of what techniques or understanding as a result of the grant: better understanding of nanoparticulate dispersion characteristics, exploration of novel photothermal compounds and increased understanding of fundamental physics behind conversion of light to heat, increased understanding of surface chemistry of metals and how to easily modify the oxide layer on many metals, macroscale material construction from nanoscale components, and also a nuanced understanding of the fundamental physics of melting and fusion of materials.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2016
Modified by: Lance R Pickens
